Comment: Endowments include both restricted and unrestricted funds. Per the [Harvard Financial Administration](https://finance.harvard.edu/endowment), unrestricted funds comprise about 20% of the endowment and can be used for any purpose. Bearing in mind that most funds are allocated to illiquid investments, that still comes to about $10.6 billion as of the most recent valuation ($53.4 billion), or $534 million in unrestricted investment income assuming 5% annual rate of return.  The problem with government grants is that universities use creative accounting to negotiate unreasonably high indirect cost rates and avoid accountability, so certain operating expenses that could be paid out of endowment distributions are instead borne at the taxpayer’s expense. That was the whole thing behind the NIH’s 15% cap on indirect cost rates earlier this year, which I think is still held up in the courts.  Edits for clarity.
